report_title: Adoption & Child Welfare Services in the US
executive_summary: The Adoption and Child Welfare Services industry provides local, traditionally in-person services and is predominately nonprofit. Since service provision is labor intensive requiring skilled employees, average profit margins are thin. Numerous regulations act as a small barrier, but changes in technology during COVID-19 have brought some changes, evidenced by growth in establishments. New ways to provide services and reach clients offer opportunities to expand geographically. Industry revenue depends on government funding and private donations which can change due to economic conditions and funding policy. Economic, demographic and social stressors also influence service need, impacting revenue volatility.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increased Entry into the Industry Drives Revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many services must be delivered locally and in person, keeping establishment size small. Innovations in delivery and method fade boundaries, minimize cost, widen margins and incentivize entry. Significant entry over the period increased average revenue.

While corporate profit decreased in 2020, donations, grants, endowments and federal funding increased, driving up average revenue. Some organizations were affected more than others based on revenue mix.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A One-Two Punch to Revenue Volatility
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The divide between payors and service users along with the nature of services lead to revenue volatility. Economic conditions, demographic changes and societal pressures can cause large swings in need and revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Funding Sources Will Continue to Support Performance
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Federal funding, corporate profit and per capita disposable income are expected to remain positive, bolstering revenue from donations, grants and contributions.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demographics and Local Funding Determine Location
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The need will rise due to poverty rate increases, more children aged nine and younger, and family stressors expanding the number needing foster care.
Platforms matching clients and services with improved outcomes will pressure investment. Telehealth and mobile apps expanding reach will increase competition.

industry_definition: This industry includes nonresidential social assistance services for children and young adults. Private sector and nonprofit establishments offer services in adoption, foster care placement, drug prevention, guidance, life skills training and positive social development. Excludes orphanages, group homes, day-care, youth sports centers/teams/leagues and scouting organizations.
key_trends: Demand volatility is a direct result of economic disruption from COVID-19
Public funding at the federal and state levels is the industry's largest source of revenue
Enterprise growth has outpaced industry employment, amplifying labor competition
The outlook period will see continued economic recovery and less volatility
Federal funding for social services is expected to stall over the five years to 2028
Tailwinds will incentivize new industry entrants, increasing industry employment

market_segmentation.segment_description: Government funding is expected to be the largest source of revenue. States and tribal associations receive federal funding through block grants, which are large sums of money granted by the national government with only general provisions as to how it is to be spent. Conversely, categorical grants have stricter and more particular requirements on how money is spent. Most industry enterprises are not-for-profit organizations and rely on government grants for a significant portion of revenue. This segment benefited from COVID-19 aid.

Grants, contributions and donations from private entities are the second-largest source of company revenue. This revenue source depends on corporate profit and per capita disposable income, which affect corporations' and individuals' ability to donate and support not-for-profit efforts in their communities.

Other industry revenue is generated through fees for various services, including counseling and adoption facilitation. Most organizations are not-for-profit and aim to provide services to those with little to no financial support, so individuals' funding for services represents the smallest share of industry revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: An industry establishment's revenue is driven, in part, by spending at the federal, state and tribal levels.
The revenue portion generated through both corporate and individual donations fluctuates depending on the levels of corporate profit and per capita disposable income.
Economic, demographic and social factors drive the need for adoption, youth, and other child welfare services.
Government rules and policies determine available funding and are a bridge between the demand and supply of services since those in need cannot pay for services without government or private funding.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Although children adopted through this industry may be brought into the country from abroad, the fees collected by industry operators reflect reimbursement for legal expenses and the placement service itself. Therefore, operators generate revenue by coordinating and providing a service. Due to the service-based nature of this industry's activities, there is no import or export of goods and, consequently, no international trade.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes, Southwest and Plains regions' shares of establishments fall short of their population shares. Since a portion of services sought is related to population, underserved regions based on population may support profitable entry and expansion.

The share of establishments surpasses the population share in New England, Rocky Mountains, Southeast, West and Mid-Atlantic, indicating adequate provision. Such regions may possess conditions that boost the need for child welfare services, including poverty and a larger youth demographic.

California's share of establishments nearly equals the state's population, but some services may be underserved. Texas' share of the population surpasses its share of industry locations, indicating an undersupply of services and potentially profitable entry in some local markets. New York and Florida provide services in excess of the population's share, indicating more significant needs, possibly more concentration and intense competition for clients.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Adoption and Safe Families Act (ASFA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: ASFA promotes the timely placement of children in permanent homes through adoption or guardianship. ASFA requires states to make reasonable efforts to prevent the removal of a child from their home but also establishes strict timelines for achieving permanency for children who cannot safely return to their birth families.

ICWA, established in 1978, has strict requirements for the placement of Native American children in foster care or adoption and requires that states provide notice to and obtain consent from the child's tribe before making any placement decisions.
Established in 1993, this federal law prevents discrimination in adoption and foster care placements on the basis of race, ethnicity or national origin.
These provisions build on MEPA and require states to document their efforts to recruit and consider adoptive families of different racial and ethnic backgrounds.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FOSTERING CONNECTIONS TO SUCCESS AND INCREASING ADOPTIONS ACT (2008)
regulations_points.regulation_description: This act extended federal foster care and adoption assistance to age 21. It provided new financial incentives for states to increase the number of children who are adopted out of foster care, including incentives for adopting older children and children with special needs.

regulations_points.regulation_title: CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES IMPROVEMENT AND INNOVATION ACT (CFSA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The CFSA included provisions designed to improve child welfare outcomes, requiring states to develop and implement plans to improve their child welfare systems, emphasize family preservation and reunification, increase accountability and improve data collection and systems.

regulations_points.regulation_title: JUVENILE JUSTICE AND DELINQUENCY PREVENTION ACT (JJDPA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: JJDPA authorizes federal funding for projects to reduce juvenile delinquency and improve outcomes for youth who come into contact with the justice system.

regulations_points.regulation_title: HEALTH INSURANCE PORTABILITY AND ACCOUNTABILITY ACT (HIPAA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: HIPAA requires that healthcare providers take steps to protect the privacy and security of an individual's health information and may apply to information about youth in youth services programs.

basis_points.basis_title: Companies providing assistance in adoption and other child welfare services compete for funding and clients
basis_points.basis_description: nevertheless, most have a collaborative relationship with those doing similar work, working to improve the communities in which they operate.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Government funding and nonprofit structure enforce a small firm size
concentration_points.concentration_description: With constrained funding sources and reliance on grants and donations, most organizations cannot support a large workforce. Federal funding for industry-relevant programs is spread out across states and then over different local organizations, further increasing fragmentation.

concentration_points.concentration_title: State and Local Regulations Keep Services Fragmented Nationally
concentration_points.concentration_description: States administer welfare programs and regulations that can differ widely. Organizations can benefit from diverse regulations by providing niche services, taking advantage of economies of scale and reputation for a particular service segment.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Service Providers Have Significant Other Expenses and Marketing Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Assisting those seeking child care services includes fundraising expenses, legal fees, insurance costs, repair and maintenance, IT services and travel.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Child welfare services are characterized by a low degree of capital intensity. In 2023, for every $1.00 spent on wages, service providers are expected to allocate $0.06 toward capital investments.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Government Funding Swings Create Revenue Surges
volatility_points.volatility_description: As the largest payor of services, notable federal funding increases throughout most of the current period contributed to moderate revenue volatility as more funds create a greater pool of those seeking adoption and child welfare services.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Corporate Profit and Poverty Rates Prop Up Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Many child welfare services providers rely on private and public charitable contributions, as well as individual and corporate donations, which fluctuate with the health of the broader economy.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many adoption and child welfare services companies have adequate information technology systems in place to maintain client records, demonstrate funds use and prove compliance with grant or donation funding requirements.

FAQs.question: How does your company market its services to the wider community? Does your organization employ social media to do so?
FAQs.answer: Industry organizations primarily cater to the needs of children, but also offer some general social assistance services and benefit from broad awareness.

FAQs.question: How does your company target key potential markets?
FAQs.answer: Being able to identify and court potential donors is key to success in the industry, since almost half of funding comes from public and private grants.

FAQs.question: Is your company geographically positioned in communities where there is a strong need for its services?
FAQs.answer: The industry's services are particularly beneficial to those living near or below the poverty line, and being close to these communities is vital.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage operating expenses to ensure maximum profitability?
FAQs.answer: Many organizations recruit volunteers to trim labor costs, since the majority of industry organizations operate on a nonprofit basis.

FAQs.question: Has your organization been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Although some administrative tasks may be automated, the industry's core services are very labor-intensive, requiring in-person interactions between children and trained professionals.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve internal processes?
FAQs.answer: Demonstrating an ability to use grant funding and donations efficiently is a key competitive factor in the industry, so investments in tracking internal processes are valuable.

FAQs.question: How does your company keep up with varying regulations across states?
FAQs.answer: Many large, national organizations have local subsidiaries, which assist in compliance at the state and municipal levels.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Failure to adequately monitor the safety of environments in which children are cared for can not only lead to regulatory issues but also severe damage to an organization's public relations.

FAQs.question: How does your organization keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: The majority of the industry's organizations are nonprofit, which puts a premium on cost control, as budgets contend with uncertainty in public funding and private giving.

FAQs.question: Has your company looked into financing options for low-income individuals and/or families?
FAQs.answer: A majority of the industry's revenue comes from program fees, but clients are often unable to pay them, so it is important for organizations to seek financing arrangements and subsidies.

FAQs.question: Does your organization rely on membership fees, contributions, donations, or fund raisers? What can your company do to increase the reliability of its income?
FAQs.answer: Many industry organizations are nonprofits and rely on various types of government funding for a substantial portion of revenue.

FAQs.question: Does your organization have a good reputation? How does your company measure and maintain a positive reputation in this industry?
FAQs.answer: Families will want to use adoption agencies with a good reputation and that can be trusted.

FAQs.question: Does your organization monitor changes in government regulations? Has it had any issues with government regulations in the past?
FAQs.answer: Operators must meet all regulations by federal, state and regulatory bodies especially concerning the management and reporting of cash flows.

FAQs.question: How will a falling poverty rate affect demand for your company's services? How does your organization adjust to periods of higher demand in response to a higher poverty rate?
FAQs.answer: The poverty rate measures the percentage of the population that lives below the federal poverty line. When the poverty rate increases, families have greater difficulty providing for children.

FAQs.question: Does your company expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How can your organization capitalize on rising disposable incomes?
FAQs.answer: This industry is dependent on individual charitable contributions and membership fees for funding. Increases in per capita disposable income tends to drive growth in donation revenues.

FAQs.question: How has federal funding for your organization changed in recent years? How can your organization prepare for cuts in federal funding?
FAQs.answer: Federal funding for social services provides support for foster care and adoption services, youth counseling programs, child welfare centers, job training programs and other services.
